Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to the UH-1Y and AH-1W/Z aircraft and related systems. The overall goals associated with these modifications are to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready-based aircraft and ready-for-tasking rates, eliminate safety hazards, improve survivability, fulfill operational requirements, remedy obsolescence, and sustain/improve mission capability in support of the Marine Air Ground Task Force and joint operations worldwide.

The H-1 Series modifications within this line item are grouped into three focus areas: H-1 Avionics Improvements (OSIP 015-12), H-1 Sensors and Weapons Improvements (OSIP 016-12), and H-1 Air Vehicle Improvements (OSIP 013-14). 

The mission of the UH-1Y utility helicopter is to provide command and control and combat assault support under day/night and adverse weather conditions and special operations support: supporting arms coordination and aeromedical evacuation. The H-1 aircraft provide local civilian and military search and rescue support, as well as augmenting Department of Homeland Security resources. The AH-1W/Z are tandem-seat, two-place attack helicopters.  The mission of the AH-1W/Z attack helicopter is to provide rotary wing close air support, anti-armor, armed escort, armed/visual reconnaissance, anti-helicopter and point air defense and fire support coordination during day/night conditions. The current armament of the AH-1W/Z includes the Sidewinder and Hellfire missile systems, a chin-mounted 20mm turret gun, and a wide variety of forward-firing and gravity-released external stores. 

The aircraft inventory objective for the UH-1Y for FY 2019 is projected to be 154 aircraft.
The aircraft inventory objective for the AH-1Z for FY 2019 is projected to be 136 aircraft. 
The aircraft inventory objective for the AH-1W for FY 2019 is projected to be 47 aircraft.

Justification.val:
Basis for FY 2019 Budget Request:  Funds are requested in FY 2019 for modifications to the UH-1Y and AH-1Z aircraft and related air vehicle, avionics, sensors, and weapons systems.

FY 2017 OCO Funds realigned between OSIP 15-12 and OSIP 16-12 for Distributed Aperture Infrared Countermeasures (DAIRCM) due to Integrated Product Team (IPT) restructure.

The Cost to Complete should be $896.882 vice $929.051 and the Total Cost should be $2,302.796 vice $2,334,965.

The FY 2019 funding request was reduced by $0.627M to reflect the Department of Navy's effort to support the Office of Management and Budget directed reforms for Efficiency and Effectiveness that include a lean, accountable, more efficient government.

Name.@footnote: FY 2019 Data is required for Embedded GPS Inertial (EGI).

Increase in FY 2019 is due to MC, EGI, SATCOM, High Definition Smart Displays and GPS.  The FY 2019 funding request was reduced by $0.627M to reflect the Department of Navy's effort to support the Office of Management and Budget directed reforms for Efficiency and Effectiveness that include a lean, accountable, more efficient government.

DI Full Motion Video (FMV) supports UUNS CDTS# 11061UA.  The separation of DI-FMV was made to reflect a phase 1 which includes a 2 tail-mounted antennas and a carry-on ANW2 waveform capability, which provides an interim capability to meet the Urgent Universal Needs Statement.

The separation of DI-FMV was made to reflect a Phase 2 due to the increased costs associated with adding an additional antenna to provide FMV coverage forward of the aircraft, and integrating the ANW2 waveform capability as a permanent solution.
Procurement and retrofit of 349 upgraded Embedded GPS Inertial (EGI) systems which includes a new EGI/Radar Altimeter (RADALT) and a new Anti-jam GPS antenna beginning in FY 2019.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) incorporates changes to H-1 avionics systems, specifically attacking the highest readiness degraders to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready based aircraft and ready- for-tasking rates. Improvements to safety of flight, maintenance, obsolescence (Diminishing Manufacturing Sources/Material Shortages), and readiness degrader items will yield a more interoperable and survivable H-1 force to sustain warfighter capability in support of worldwide operations. Systems modified and improved on H-1 aircraft will leverage common architectures and utilize existing technology to the maximum extent practicable to minimize development and procurement costs and to reduce the time to field the modifications.

Specific systems associated with this OSIP are: Mission Computer, Mission Computer Harness for improved video, Digital Map, Flight Control Computer, Wiring Integration Remote Terminals, flight data recorders, maintenance data recorders, video recorders, Digital Video Recorders (DVR), data loaders, air data systems, Multi-Function Displays (MFD), Smart Displays, Dual Function Displays (DFD), interoperable video and digital data links (Tactical Video Data Links and Full Motion Video (FMV)) for Variable Message Format with an Aircraft Network Switch, Data Transfer System and Data Storage Unit. Communication systems, Mobile User Objective System (MUOS), Wireless Inter-Communications Systems (WICS), Identification Friend or Foe system, Inertial Navigation System, Global Positioning System (GPS) Inertial (EGI), Aircraft Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADS-B), Selective Availability Anti-Spoofing Module (SAASM), GPS non-precision approach capability and Navigation Warfare (NAVWAR) GPS signal protection efforts such as Anti-Jam Antenna, radar altimeter, Blue Force Tracker, and Joint Battlefield Command - Platform (JBC-P). Safety system modifications are required for DFD knob, collision avoidance systems, Degraded Visual Environment, Ground Proximity Warning System, Terrain Awareness Warning System, Crash Survivable Flight Incident Recorder, Improved Vehicle Health and Monitoring System (IMD HUMS) and the Enhanced Digital Ground Station (EDGS) along with Military Flight Operations Quality Assurance.
 
System Configuration Set (SCS) updates are required for avionics component upgrades and interface modifications to ensure integration of platform weapons and sensors. Other focus areas will include Weapon Repairable Assembly modifications to improve avionics and weapons system reliability, maintainability, accuracy and interoperability.


DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:

Name.@footnote: Increases in FY 2019 provides publications for APR-39D(V)2 and TSS Block Upgrade.
Increases in FY 2019 provides logistics support for APR-39D(V)2 and TSS Block Upgrade.
Increases in FY 2019 provides technical support for APR-39D(V)2 and TSS Block Upgrade.

The UH-1Y is only equipped with the legacy APR-39D(V)2 system. Increase in FY 2019 with the modification of (4) UH-1Y's allows the Marine Corps the flexibility to deploy aircraft with a common digital processor type, that will enhance situational awareness, enhance effectiveness and suitability in complex, hostile environments in support of Marine Expeditionary Operations.

FY 2017 OCO funding for Distributed Aperture Infrared Countermeasures (DAIRCM) has moved to OSIP 16-12, Sensors & Weapons IPT, from OSIP 15-12, Avionics IPT. DAIRCM funds, provided under the Rapid Acquisition Authority (RAA) are to complete installation of the Joint Urgent Operational Need Statement (JUONS) DAIRCM system on 18 fleet H-1 aircraft to support deployments with the upgraded IR/LASER threat detection system.
Increase in FY 2019 NRE is for APR-39D(V)2 to complete retrofit kit in order to begin fleet installation of the upgraded RADAR detection system.

Name.val: 2.1.1) BRITE Star BLK II Laser Spot Tracker (UH-1Y) - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: The USMC H-1 Operating Forces Capabilities Planning Document identifies the need for an electro-optical system capable of automatically detecting laser designator energy for purposes of target handoff operations. The Target Sight System (TSS) Block Upgrade includes the TSS Laser Spot Tracker, Turret Electronic Unit, and High Definition upgrade to enable the AH-1Z to detect, acquire, and track laser designator energy for more expeditious target handoff and engagement. Procurement of equipment begins in FY 2019.
Name.val: 2.1.2) Target Sight System (TSS) Block Upgrade (AH-1Z) - Organic

Name.@footnote: Readiness increase in FY 2017 is for the procurement of Optimized TopOwl (OTO) display module external protection kits. The OTO display modules have experienced a significant failure rate and the design is being improved during FY 2017 to address the failure modes.

Name.@footnote: The UH-1Y is only equipped with the legacy APR-39D(V)2 system. Increase in FY 2019 with the modification of (4) UH-1Y's allows the Marine Corps the flexibility to deploy aircraft with a common digital processor type, that will enhance situational awareness, enhance effectiveness and suitability in complex, hostile environments in support of Marine Expeditionary Operations.

Increase in FY 2018 Installation Equipment N/R (material, engineering and test) required for Target Sight Sensor (TSS) Block Upgrade. Without the N/R TSS block upgrade will be forced to continue utilizing the current TSS which has deficiencies that impact AH-1Z situational awareness and reduces the capability in the employment of the Joint Air To Ground Missile (JAGM) scheduled to IOC in FY 2019.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) incorporates changes to H-1 mission systems sensors, Helmet Mounted Sight Displays (HMSD), Aircraft Survivability Equipment (ASE), and weapon systems, specifically attacking the highest readiness degraders to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready-based aircraft and ready-for-tasking rates. Improvements to safety of flight, maintenance, obsolescence (Diminishing Manufacturing Sources/Material Shortages), aircrew situational awareness and readiness degrader items will yield a more interoperable and survivable H-1 force to sustain warfighter capability in support of worldwide operations. Systems modified and improved on H-1 aircraft will leverage common avionics architectures to the extent possible to mitigate development, procurement costs and fielding timelines.  The modifications will specifically address enhancing capabilities, readiness and sensor fusion with the entire ASE, HMSD, and weapons suite to improve both battlefield and situational awareness.

This OSIP addresses the U.S. Marine Corps' operational requirement to detect, identify, and destroy target sets with the precision guided munitions during day, night, and adverse weather conditions.  Sensor systems include the Target Sight System (TSS), and BRITE Star Block II, which currently provide a night/adverse weather Forward-Looking Infrared and laser designation for the H-1 series helicopter.  Improvements to H-1 series helicopters' weapons systems include both air to ground and air to air missiles, rocket systems, 20mm turreted gun system reliability/obsolescence and weapons accuracy improvement efforts.  These weapon systems include all Precision Guided Munitions, (Advanced Precision Kill Weapon System (APKWS), the Hellfire family of missiles, inclusive of the M299 Hellfire launcher and the Joint Air To Ground (JAGM), AIM-9X integration, the M197 20MM Turreted Gun System, associated Aviation Armament Equipment (AAE), 20MM Linkless Feed System (LFS), crew served weapons Helicopter Armament Systems (HAS), and the Digital Rocket Launcher (DRL) and associated Airborne Weapon Support Equipment (AWSE).  Helmet Mounted Sight and Display (HMSD) system, improvements to the Optimized Top Owl (OTO), include Night and Day Module Optic Reliability Improvements, helmet to aircraft integration improvements as well as helmet mapping improvements.  HMSD safety initiatives addressed by this OSIP include, but not limited to, spatial disorientation issues caused by Degraded Visual Environments (DVE), human factor improvements to helmet design, integration and optics improvements. For Sensor Improvements, this OSIP will address TSS Block Upgrades/Modifications to add a Laser Spot Tracker (LST) capability to detect, acquire and track laser designator signatures; Infra-Red (IR) laser pointing devices; add a high definition camera/telescope to increase detection, recognition, and identification ranges. This improvement will upgrade existing gimbal processors, optimize program security initiatives, address AC network and data link capabilities as well as improve upon overall HMSD, weapon and sensor fusion to improve weapons accuracy.  The H-1 Upgrades Aircraft Survivability Equipment (ASE) suite currently consists of the AN/APR-39B(V)2 RWR, AAR-47B(V)2 Missile Warning Systems (MWS) and the AN/ALE-47 Countermeasures Dispensing System (CMDS).  The AN/APR-39B(V)2 currently installed in the AH-1Z and UH-1Y is obsolete and must be replaced by the AN/APR-39D(V)2.  In addition to the radar detection upgrades of the APR-39D(V)2, IR detection and countermeasures upgrades will be implemented with the integration of the Distributed Aperture Infrared Countermeasures (DAIRCM) system, and processor upgrades in the ALE-47 countermeasures dispensing set.  ASE Suite upgrades are inherent to successful Digital Interoperability and Electronic Warfare (EW) initiatives, such as the integration of the Intrepid Tiger (IT II), that will ensure the H-1 platform can effectively meet network ready requirements.  The interoperability with other battle management systems, provides aircrew with improved situational awareness, battlefield awareness and incorporates an EW capability.  
 
DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  FY 2016 completed BRITE Star BLK II Laser Spot Tracker integration efforts, Target Sight System (TSS) Coherent Radiation Electronics Interface Unit (CREIU) and IR Pointer integration. These critical fleet requirements provide enhanced targeting capabilities to support Marine Expeditionary Unit deployments.  FY 2017 began JUONS DAIRCM A-kit part procurement and fabrication, and DAIRCM system installation for 2 x H-1 test aircraft.

Name.@footnote: Readiness increase in FY 2017 for (102) Inverters will impact readiness of the UH-1Y Fleet significantly. Existing UH-1Y inverters are currently experiencing high rates of failure (low reliability) which is having a negative effect on the readiness of the UH-1Y Fleet. Reports show these inverters have a Mean Time Between Failure (MTBF) average of 263 hrs. The new DSP-type inverter calculated MTBF is 3,468 hrs. Replacing old inverters with new DSP-type inverters increases time between replacement by ~3,205 hours per unit.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) incorporates a number of modifications to H-1 air vehicle systems, specifically attacking the highest readiness degraders to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready-based aircraft and ready-for-tasking rates. Improvements to safety of flight, maintenance, obsolescence (Diminishing Manufacturing Sources/Material Shortages), and readiness degrader items will yield a more interoperable and survivable H-1 force to sustain warfighter capability in support of worldwide operations.

Planned modifications cover airframes (structural and air vehicle systems), propulsion, survivability, reliability and maintainability, fuel systems, electrical power, drives, engines, rotors, flying qualities, flight controls, human factors, systems thermodynamics, and weight and balance.  Particular focus is on continuously reducing total ownership costs by increasing component time on the aircraft.  During full scale development testing of the H-1 Upgrades aircraft, data evaluation showed that incorporation of redesigned components applicable to the critical load paths will significantly increase the service life of the aircraft and components to meet the life limit of 10,000 flight hours.  

Safety programs include, cargo door latch, external lights, and mission grip mounts. Reliability and maintainability modifications items include, the aircraft electrical system, power distribution system, fuel cells, canopy frame, bushings, blade fold rack, gearboxes, standpipes, fuselage/cabin/seats, external lights, engine mount and tail boom bearings, main and tail rotor components, aircraft Nickel Cadmium battery, hydraulic distribution, weight reduction initiatives, swashplate, integrated mechanical diagnostic system, clearances, drive system, systems heating/cooling, corrosion/water intrusion control, rotor blade and gun turret covers, engine cowlings, and airframe structural robustness including access panels.  Dynamic Component Reliability includes improvements/upgrades to: rotor brake system, Main Rotor Gear Box (MRGB) PC2 pump quill, desiccant breather, input quills, MRGB tiltball, and main rotor mast.  Survivability modifications include, Improved Defensive Armament System (IDAS) for carrying stores (UH-1Y machine guns, rocket pods, fuel tanks, etc.), and armored flooring. Electrical power modifications include generators and inverters.

Other structural modifications include: swash plate assembly, clamp ring assembly, composite elevator, tail boom assembly, main rotor blades, and canopies. Human factor improvements include Aircrew Restraint System (ARS).  Propulsion improvements to tail boom wiring and drives.  Thermal cooling improvements include Environmental Cooling System (ECS).


DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Rotor Break System specification completed.  PC2 Quill housing design completed.  Cargo door latch (a safety issue correction) Critical Design Review (CDR) completed.
